title: How Montana’s LR-131 ‘Born-Alive’ referendum failed
excerpt:
Organized opposition to the initiative spent hundreds of thousands of dollars and countless volunteer hours trying to get its message to as many Montana voters as possible. As the dust settled on last week’s election, the campaign’s defeat of LR-131 became one of a handful of nationwide wins for the reproductive rights movement, and a possible signal of caution for Republican lawmakers hoping to put similar bills before voters in upcoming election cycles.

title: Ann Bukacek and John Repke: Two views vie for one seat on the PSC
excerpt:

Republican Ann Bukacek’s conservative platform has helped launch the Flathead Valley physician into the regulatory arena. On Nov. 8 voters will pick one to serve on the state’s influential Public Service Commission.

title: The divergent energy visions of Montana’s U.S. House candidates
excerpt:
U.S. House candidates Ryan Zinke and Monica Tranel have both worked on energy issues on public and private payrolls. Zinke, a Republican, underscores the importance of “American energy independence” and emphasizes the role of fossil fuels in that vision. Tranel, a Democrat, prioritizes a transition to clean energy that “has to start quickly and accelerate.”

title: Tschida, Curdy face off in race for key state Senate seat
excerpt:
Diane Sands’ term-limited departure leaves an open path for either party to take Senate District 49 in an election year when Democrats hope to hold as much ground as possible against a surging Montana GOP that needs only two more seats to achieve a bicameral legislative supermajority. The district is at the center of both ambitions, and in the background are major policy debates around abortion, housing affordability and the economy.

title: Recounts results confirm Bukacek won utility board GOP primary
excerpt:
Ballot recounts conducted in four counties, which concluded Monday, confirm that Flathead Valley internal medicine doctor Ann “Annie” Bukacek has won the Republican primary for a seat on the five-member board that regulates the state’s monopoly utility power, water, garbage and telecommunications companies. She defeated Rep. Derek Skees and two other challengers in the tight race.

title: Bukacek presumptive winner of Republican PSC primary
excerpt:
The latest count for the District 5 Public Service Commission GOP primary puts Flathead Valley physician Ann “Annie” Bukacek 87 votes ahead of termed-out state legislator Derek Skees. Though Bukacek’s lead has grown by 13 votes since the June 8 count, the margin is still tight enough — within half of 1% — that the secretary of state has it flagged as being one of just three primary races that could be eligible for a recount. Skees hasn’t said if he’ll pursue a recount.

title: Montana congressional candidates make final primary push
excerpt:
Candidates vying for Montana’s two congressional districts are in the final sprint of their primary campaigns leading up to the June 7 election. In the Western district, five Republicans and three Democrats are jockeying to represent their party on the November ballot. One Libertarian candidate is running unopposed. In the Eastern district, four Republicans, including incumbent Rep. Matt Rosendale, are competing to represent their party alongside three Democratic candidates and three Libertarians.

title: Meet the PSC candidates who want to regulate your rates
excerpt:
Originally formed in 1907 to oversee railroad operations, the five-member Public Service Commission regulates monopolies in the power, natural gas, water, telecommunications and garbage collection industries. This year’s PSC race has drawn an eclectic mix of candidates vying for two open seats on the commission — among the highest-paid positions in state government — and each candidate is pitching a different understanding of the commission’s role.

title: Republican support colors Montana Supreme Court race
excerpt:
In his campaign for the Montana Supreme Court seat currently held by Justice Ingrid Gustafson, who is seeking re-election, attorney James Brown is receiving the race’s most overtly partisan support from a long list of elected Republicans. This month, Brown referenced Gov. Greg Gianforte’s support of his candidacy when he told attendees at a candidate event in Butte that the governor had asked him to consider entering the race.

title: The politics driving the Montana Supreme Court races
excerpt:
Members of the state’s highest court have spent much of the last year defending their branch of government while prominent Republican officials publicly challenge the judiciary and scrutinize its operations. Now, some of those same Republican officials have thrown their weight behind a particular candidate and levied public smears against both incumbents, inserting overtly partisan messaging into traditionally nonpartisan races.
